page.title: 04FORCETT - The Hall Dovecote
page.content: This dovecote is believed to be of a unique design, being hexagonal in shape, built of stone under a slate roof and with an arched doorway in each of its sides thus creating the impression of its being supported on pillars. It is relatively small and stands in a small grass paddock. It is still used by semi-wild pigeons of the homing variety for roosting and nesting purposes. In the past pigeons and doves were taken from this cote as a source of meat for the kitchen table, they also provided sport in the form of shooting targets for local gentry. Today, the pigeons occupy the cote largely undisturbed and their place as live targets has been taken by clay discs, projected by mechanical means to simulate a bird in flight and which is shot at by 'sportsmen' using 12-bore shotguns.
